abstract.p: This document defines a set of extension functions to perform cryptographic operations. These functions are related to XML Digital Signature, to encryption and decryption, and to hashing and digesting of messages. They have been designed to be compatible with and , as well as any other standard based on .
The functions are defined on the datatypes defined in and . Also, the functions are defined on nodes and node sequences as defined in the and are following the good practices inferred from .

div1.head: Status of this document
div1.p: This document is in an interim draft stage. Comments are welcomed at public-expath@w3.org mailing list (archive).

div1.head: Introduction
div1.p: Cryptography is the science of communicating in secret code, by conversion of data with the help of a key. In modern times, cryptography is necessary when communicating over any untrusted medium, particularly the Internet.

Encryption of data can be of two types: symmetric and asymmetric. Symmetric encryption means that the same key is used for encryption and decryption. Asymmetric encryption means that a message can be encrypted by using a key that is public, but the decryption can be made only by using a private key, which form a pair with the respective public key.
A related technique of cryptography is to apply a one-way hash or digest function to data; replicating the operation with the same data and function can ensure the integrity of the data.

div2.head: Namespace conventions
div2.p: The module defined by this document defines functions and elements in the namespace http://expath.org/ns/crypto. In this document, the crypto prefix, when used, is bound to this namespace URI.
Error codes are defined in the same namespace (http://expath.org/ns/crypto), and in this document are displayed with the same prefix, crypto.

div2.head: Error management
div2.p: Error conditions are identified by a code (a QName). When such an error condition is reached during the execution of the function, a dynamic error is thrown, with the corresponding error code (as if the standard XPath function error had been called).

div2.head: The crypto:hash function
div2.p: This function generates a "message digest" of the input data, by using a cryptographic algorithm. It returns the hash value as xs:base64Binary, (identifier http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#base64, see , section 6.1 Algorithm Identifiers and Implementation Requirements).
div2.eg: crypto:hash($data as xs:anyAtomicType, $algorithm as xs:string) as xs:base64Binary

item.p: $data is the data to be hashed. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary.
$algorithm is the cryptographic hashing algorithm. If it is specified an unsupported algorithm, this is an error .

div2.head: The crypto:hmac function
div2.p: HMAC (Keyed-Hashing for Message Authentication) is a mechanism for message authentication using cryptographic hash functions. HMAC can be used with any iterative cryptographic hash function in combination with a secret shared key. Typically, message authentication codes are used between two parties that share a secret key in order to validate information transmitted between these parties.
This function generates a message authentication code, based on the input message, by using a cryptographic algorithm and a secret key.
div2.eg: crypto:hmac($data as xs:anyAtomicType, $key as xs:anyAtomicType, $algorithm as xs:string) as xs:base64Binary

item.p: $data is the data to be authenticated. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary.
$key is the secret key used for calculating the authentication code. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary.

$algorithm is the cryptographic hashing algorithm. The default value is "HMAC-SHA1" (identifier http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#hmac-sha1, see , section 6.1 Algorithm Identifiers and Implementation Requirements). If it is specified an unsupported algorithm, this is an error .

div1.head: XML Digital Signature
div1.p: A digital signature is a technique to certify that a digital document is authentic. This means that the origin of the document is known and there is the ability to identify if the digital document has been changed since the digital signature was applied to it. This is done by means of a cryptographic transformation.
This function can apply an XML digital signature to one or more resources. There are three types of XML digital signatures, namely enveloped, enveloping, and detached signatures.
According to , the enveloped and enveloping signatures are applied to the same digital resource (and XML document), while the detached signatures can be applied to more than one digital resources.
The designation of these digital resources is to be made based upon the explanations given in .
In order to reference these digital resources, this function is using an XML syntax inspired by . For details, see below the parameter $resources.

div2.head: The crypto:generate-signature function
div2.p: The function has its parameters passed as a map(xs:string, item()). If any of these parameters is missing, a default value will be used instead. After the function's signature, an example of parameters is given.
div2.eg: crypto:generate-signature($data as document()?, $parameters as map(xs:string, item()+)?) as document()*

item.p: $data is the data to be signed.
$parameters represent the parameters used for generating the XML digital signature. For details regarding these parameters, see the table and the example below.

tr.td:

inclusive-1.1, identifier http://www.w3.org/2006/12/xml-c14n11, for XML 1.1 documents, see , section 6.5.2 Canonical XML 1.1.
inclusive-with-comments-1.1, identifier http://www.w3.org/2006/12/xml-c14n11#WithComments, for XML 1.1 documents, see , section 6.5.2 Canonical XML 1.1.
inclusive-1.0, identifier http://www.w3.org/TR/2001/REC-xml-c14n-20010315, for XML 1.0 documents, see , section 6.5.1 Canonical XML 1.0.

exclusive, identifier http://www.w3.org/2001/10/xml-exc-c14n#, see , section 4. Use in XML Security.
exclusive-with-comments, identifier http://www.w3.org/2001/10/xml-exc-c14n#WithComments, see , section 4. Use in XML Security.

The digest algorithm to be applied to the signed object. Possible values are: "SHA1" (identifier http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#sha1, see , section 6.1 Algorithm Identifiers and Implementation Requirements), which is the default value. Other recommended values are: "SHA256", and "SHA512". If the parameter specifies an unsupported algorithm, this is an error . (Optional)

The algorithm used for signature generation and validation. The default value is "DSAwithSHA1" (identifier http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#dsa-sha1, see , section 6.1 Algorithm Identifiers and Implementation Requirements). Another value is "RSAwithSHA1" (identifier http://www.w3.org/2000/09/xmldsig#rsa-sha1, see , section 6.1 Algorithm Identifiers and Implementation Requirements). If the parameter specifies an unsupported algorithm, this is an error . (Optional)
The namespace prefix for signature. If this parameter is not provided, the default value of 'dsig' will be used. (Optional)

The method used for signing the content of signature. Possible values are: "enveloping", "enveloped", and "detached". The default value is "enveloped". If the parameter specifies an unsupported signature type, this is an error . (Optional)

The references to the digital resources to be signed. If this parameter is not provided, the whole input document will be signed. If the signature is of enveloped or enveloping type, and more than one resource is inputted to be signed, this is an error . More details about this parameter can be found at . (Optional)
The secret key used for signing. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary.(Optional)

This element contains an ordered list of Transform elements.

This element describes how the signer obtained the data object that is to be digested. The Algorithm attribute's value specifies the name of the algorithm to be applied, and the Transform element's text content provides additional data for processing using that algorithm. For more details and schema of this element, see , section 4.3.3.4 The Transforms Element.

The XPath expression to be applied to the input document, in order to get the resource to be signed. The version of XPath to be used is 1.0, plus a function named here. The Filter attribute's value provides the name of the operation (intersection, subtraction and union) used for combining the XPath-selected subtrees. For more details, see , section 6.6.3 XPath Filtering, and .

div2.head: The crypto:validate-signature function
div2.p: This function validates an XML Digital Signature.

item.p: $data is the enveloped, enveloping, or detached signature. If the Signature element cannot be found, this is an error .

div1.head: Encryption and Decryption
div1.p: Encryption represents the process of conversion of data, by using a secret key (a cipher), in a form (called cipher text) that cannot be understood by unautorized persons.
The decryption represents the reverse process, of converting encrypted data back to plain text (original text).

There are two main types of encryption: symmetric encryption, when both parties, the sender and the receiver, use the same secret key, previously exchanged, and asymmetric encryption, when a key pair, consisting of a private key and a private key, is used, of which the public key is used by sender to encrypt a message that can only be decrypted by the receiver, who holds the private key of that key pair.

div2.head: The crypto:encrypt function
div2.eg: crypto:encrypt($data as xs:anyAtomicType, $type as xs:string, $parameters as map(xs:string, item())?) as xs:base64Binary

item.p: $data is the data to be encrypted. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary. When a particular padding mechanism is requested, but is not available, this is an error . Also, when a particular padding mechanism is expected, but the data is not padded properly, this is an error .
$type is the type of encryption. Legal values: "symmetric", and "asymmetric". If the parameter has an illegal value, this is an error .
$parameters represents the parameters needed for the current operation. More details about this parameter can be found at .

key as xs:anyAtomicType is the cryptographic key used for encryption. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary. If the key is invalid, this is an error . If the length of data provided to the block cipher is incorrect, this is an error .

algorithm as xs:string is the cryptographic algorithm used for encryption. For symmetric encryption, a transformation name can be used. If the parameter specifies an unsupported algorithm or transformation name, this is an error .

iv as xs:string is the initialization vector for symmetric encryption. For asymmetric encryption, this parameter is not needed. If the initialization vector is null or it is not as it is requested by the encryption algorithm, this is an error

tr.td: This is the cryptographic key used for encryption. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary. If the key is invalid, this is an error . If the length of data provided to the block cipher is incorrect, this is an error .

This is the cryptographic algorithm used for encryption. For symmetric encryption, a transformation name can be used. If the parameter specifies an unsupported algorithm or transformation name, this is an error .

This is the initialization vector for symmetric encryption. For asymmetric encryption, this parameter is not needed. If the initialization vector is null or it is not as it is requested by the encryption algorithm, this is an error .

div2.head: The crypto:decrypt function
div2.eg: crypto:decrypt($data as xs:anyAtomicType, $type as xs:string, $parameters as map(xs:string, item())?) as xs:string

item.p: $data is the data to be decrypted. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary. When a particular padding mechanism is requested, but is not available, this is an error . Also, when a particular padding mechanism is expected, but the data is not padded properly, this is an error .
$type is the type of decryption. Legal values: "symmetric", and "asymmetric". If the parameter has an illegal value, this is an error .
$parameters represents the parameters needed for the current operation. More details about this parameter can be found at .

tr.td: This is the cryptographic key used for decryption. This parameter can be of type xs:string, xs:base64Binary, or xs:hexBinary. If the key is invalid, this is an error . If the length of data provided to the block cipher is incorrect, this is an error .

This is the cryptographic algorithm used for decryption. For symmetric decryption, a transformation name can be used. If the parameter specifies an unsupported algorithm or transformation name, this is an error .

This is the initialization vector for symmetric encryption. For asymmetric encryption, this parameter is not needed. If the initialization vector is null or it is not as it is requested by the encryption algorithm, this is an error .
